claim: Library of Alexandria would need less shelf space than Library of Congress.

supporting.text: The Library of Alexandria, while historically significant, was estimated to contain around 400,000 to 700,000 scrolls, whereas the Library of Congress holds over 170 million items, including books, maps, and recordings, requiring vastly more physical space.

attacks.text: The Library of Alexandria, while historically significant, was estimated to contain around 400,000 to 700,000 scrolls, whereas the Library of Congress holds over 170 million items, including books, maps, and recordings, requiring vastly more physical space.

Scrolls in the Library of Alexandria were often densely packed and stored in compact scroll cases, whereas modern books and items in the Library of Congress require more space due to their varied formats and sizes.

Modern digital storage methods used by the Library of Congress, such as electronic archives and cloud storage, significantly reduce the physical space needed compared to traditional scroll storage in the Library of Alexandria.

The Library of Congress also includes vast collections of non-book materials like maps, recordings, and artworks, which inherently require more space than the predominantly text-based scrolls of the Library of Alexandria.
Estimates of the Library of Alexandria's collection size vary widely, and some scholars argue it may have held far fewer scrolls than commonly believed, reducing the certainty of the comparison.
Historical accounts suggest the Library of Alexandria may have had multiple storage locations or annexes, potentially increasing its total physical footprint beyond initial estimates.
